contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox President | name=Garritson W. Gibson | smallimage=Garritson Gibson2.jpg | order=14th [[List of Presidents of Liberia|President of Liberia]] | term_start=December 11, 1900 | term_end=January 4, 1904 | vicepresident=[[Joseph D. Summerville]] | predecessor=[[William D. Coleman (politician)|William D. Coleman]] | successor=[[Arthur Barclay]] | birth_date={{birth date|1832|5|20|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Baltimore]], [[Maryland (state)|Maryland]], [[United States]] | death_date={{death date|1910|4|26|mf=y}} | death_place=[[Monrovia]], [[Liberia]] | party=[[True Whig]] }} '''Garritson Wilmaut Gibson''' (20 May 1832 – 26 April 1910) was the [[President of Liberia#List of Presidents of Liberia|14th President of Liberia]] from 11 December 1900, to 4 January 1904. Born in [[Maryland]], in the [[United States]], his family emigrated to [[Liberia]] in 1835. After receiving an education in mission schools, he returned to Maryland to study theology. Ordained a [[priest]], he served as rector of the [[Anglicanism|Episcopalian]] Trinity Church in [[Monrovia]]. He also served as Chaplain of the Liberian Senate. Later, he served as President of the Trustee Board of [[University of Liberia|Liberia College]] and at one time President of the College. President Gibson began his political life as a Justice of the Peace. With the election of [[William D. Coleman (politician)|William D. Coleman]] as president in 1896, Gibson was appointed Secretary of the Interior. He was Secretary of State when Coleman resigned in 1900, and since there was no vice-president, Gibson was chosen to succeed him. He won the election that same year, and served until 1904, when his Secretary of the Treasury, [[Arthur Barclay]], succeeded him. President Gibson died in [[Monrovia]] on April 26, 1910. He was the last Liberian president to have been born in the United States. ==Presidency (1900-1904)== Prior to attaining the presidency, Gibson had had a long career in government including serving as Secretary of the Interior and Secretary of State. In 1903, the British forced a concession of Liberian territory to Sierra Leone, but tension along that border remained high. Whenever the British and French seemed intent on enlarging at Liberia's expense the neighboring territories they already controlled, periodic appearances by U.S. warships helped discourage encroachment, even though successive American administrations rejected appeals from Monrovia for more forceful support.<ref>Liebenow, J. Gus, ''Liberia: the Quest for Democracy''. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1987</ref> ==See also== *[[History of Liberia]] ==References == <references/> ==Further reading== *see [[History of Liberia#Further reading|History of Liberia, further reading]] ==Sources and links== *Nathaniel R. Richardson, ''Liberia's Past and Present.'' London: The Diplomatic Press and Publishing Company, 1959. *see also [[History of Liberia#External links|History of Liberia, external links]] {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=[[President of Liberia]]|before=[[William D. Coleman (politician)|William D. Coleman]]|after=[[Arthur Barclay]]|years=1900–1904}} {{s-end}} {{LiberianPresidents}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Gibson, Garretson W. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Liberian politician | DATE OF BIRTH = May 20, 1832 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Maryland, United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = April 26, 1910 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Monrovia]], [[Liberia]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gibson, Garretson W.}} [[Category:Americo-Liberian people]] [[Category:1832 births]] [[Category:1910 deaths]] [[Category:Presidents of Liberia]] [[Category:Liberian educators]] [[Category:Presidents of the University of Liberia]] [[Category:True Whig Party politicians]] [[Category:People from Baltimore, Maryland]] [[Category:Government ministers of Liberia]]
